Title.evidence: A Randomised Controlled Trial of Bicruciate-Retaining versus Cruciate-Retaining Total Knee Arthroplasty

Trial_Design.evidence: In this parallel-group trial (ClinicalTrials.gov: NCT01966848), 50 patients with intact ACLs undergoing TKA were randomised

Participants.evidence: 50 patients with intact ACLs undergoing TKA

Intervention.evidence: randomised to receive either bicruciate-retaining or cruciate-retaining TKA

Objective.evidence: This study evaluates tibial component migration and patient-reported outcomes.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was maximum total point motion (MTPM) of the tibial component at 2 years

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and patients were blinded to allocation.

Number_Randomised.evidence: 50 patients with intact ACLs undergoing TKA were randomised

Number_Analysed.evidence: At 2 years, 22 bicruciate-retaining and 23 cruciate-retaining patients were analysed.

Result_Outcome.evidence: No significant difference in MTPM was found (median MTPM: 0.52 mm vs. 0.42 mm, p = 0.63).

Harms.evidence: Three bicruciate-retaining patients required arthroscopic manipulation, and one had a tibial fracture requiring revision.
